Some newspaper printing errors have been corrected using official sources.

TITLE: Sir W. Birdwood in London
HISTORY: General Sir William Birdwood, Commander in Chief of the Australasian Forces travelled to London after spending several days in France. In London he met with His Majesty the King at Windsor Castle where he was invested with the insignia of a Knight Commander of the Star of India and a Knight Commander of St. Michael and St. George. He also took time to visit Australian wounded at Harefield Convelescent Hospital. He was accompanied by Lady Birdwood.;Heroes of the Great War Indexing Project - over 30,000 newspaper references to notices published in the South Australian newspaper 'The Chronicle' between 1915 and 1919 under various headings including 'Heroes of the Great War', 'Heroes of the Empire', 'Died on Active Service' and 'Biographical'. TITLE: Lt. H. V. Throssell V.C. visits Prince Alfred College
HISTORY: An old Prince Alfred College boy, Lt. Throssell, was given an enthusiastic reception when he visited the college on June 7. TITLE: [Trooper F. E. Hyde]
HISTORY: Trooper Francis Edward Hyde of the 1st Remount section, 'was probably the oldest man in South Australia to enlist in World War 1.' He enlisted at the age of 69, stating his age as 49 and passed all medical and riding tests. He was in fact born in Taunton, Somersetshire in 1846. After spending four months serving in Egypt he was seized with rheumatic fever and while spending six weeks in hospital accidently admitted his age to Colonel Mausby, the head physician at the hospital. Trooper Hyde was previously the station manager of Lake Albert station for 40 years and had vast experience with horses and was very active.  He was discharged from service and returned to Adelaide to take up a position with the State Electoral Department.;Heroes of the Great War Indexing Project - over 30,000 newspaper references to notices published in the South Australian newspaper 'The Chronicle' between 1915 and 1919 under various headings including 'Heroes of the Great War', 'Heroes of the Empire', 'Died on Active Service' and 'Biographical'. TITLE: An M.H.R. enlists
HISTORY: Mr G.E. Yates, Member of the House of Representatives for Adelaide and member of the Labor Party announced that he had been accepted for active service. Born in Bradley, Staffordshire in 1871, he came to South Australia with his parents in 1878, was educated at the Flinders Street public school and commenced work at the age of 12 at the Wellor's grindery in Rundle Street  employed by Messrs A. Simpson and Son in Gawler Place for the previous 17 years  appointed secretary to the U.L.P. in 1911 and elected to the House of Respresentatives for Adelaide in 1914, succeeding the late Mr E.A. TITLE: [Staff nurse Blanche Atkinson]
HISTORY: Staff nurse Blanche Atkinson was the eldest daughter of Mrs M.A. Atkinson and the late Mr F.J. Atkinson of Crafers where she was born. She served at the Adelaide Hospital and in Western Australia. At the outbreak of war she went to England and joined the Royal British Nursing Association and was on staff at the Brockenhurst Military Hospital when, due to overwork, became ill and was hospitalised. She was awarded the Royal Red Cross by the King for her service and later invalided back to Adelaide where she died 9th December 1916 at Crafers.;Heroes of the Great War Indexing Project - over 30,000 newspaper references to notices published in the South Australian newspaper 'The Chronicle' between 1915 and 1919 under various headings including 'Heroes of the Great War', 'Heroes of the Empire', 'Died on Active Service' and 'Biographical'.
